Why French politics can't cope without an absolute majority
subhead: While most European countries have learned to manage their fragmented parliaments, France has failed to adapt. The 'fait majoritaire,' the political dominance of a president backed by a parliamentary majority, has so deeply shaped politics since 1962 that lawmakers have been unable to envision governments built on a base of negotiation and compromise.

title: Charlie Kirk assassination: The suspect's disconcerting profile
subhead: Tyler Robinson, arrested on Thursday night, is a 22-year-old White man who grew up in a conservative family in Utah and was a brilliant high school student. Nothing in his background supports the theory being propagated in MAGA circles that he is a far-left activist.
byline: By Arnaud Leparmentier (Saint George, (Utah) special correspondent)

title: Manae Feleu, France's not-so secret weapon at the Women's Rugby World Cup
subhead: The co-captain of Les Bleues is coming to terms with her newfound fame. She will lead her teammates in their quarterfinal against Ireland on Sunday in Exeter, England.

title: Sex workers on content platforms open up to their parents
subhead: Since the Covid-19 pandemic, pornographic content platforms have been booming, attracting young creators – mainly women – who turn to sex work for the money and independence it offers. Some choose to speak to their parents about it. Those conversations can either produce distance or bring them closer together.

Israeli intelligence admits Iran's nuclear program has not been destroyed
subhead: Israeli officials have recently provided French authorities with their own assessment of the airstrikes that targeted Tehran's nuclear arsenal in June. This information is particularly valuable to France after American intelligence agencies have halted all cooperation with their European partners regarding the Iranian nuclear program.

title: When everyday hatred turns to racist murder: 'I don't know why I lost it. I have no idea'
subhead: On May 31, Christophe Belgembe, a mechanic, fatally shot his neighbor Hichem Miraoui and tried to kill five other people in the southern French town of Puget-sur-Argens. Though he had made racist remarks for years, he struggled to explain his actions.
byline: By Lorraine de Foucher  and Jérôme Lefilliâtre

title: Economist Gabriel Zucman: 'France's new PM will have to address the proposed tax on the ultra-rich'
subhead: Zucman is the architect behind the proposal to tax the wealthiest individuals, a measure championed by the left. 'It will be very difficult to ask the French people to make sacrifices as long as billionaires pay so little in taxes,' he told Le Monde in an interview.
byline: Interview by Denis Cosnard and Pascal Riché
